source.name: Western Metropolitan Regional Council (WMRC)
source.notes: Based on WMRC official guidelines. Perth's yellow-lid bin is very restrictive: ONLY 5 material types accepted. Lids must be removed from plastic. Container Deposit Scheme (10c refund) available.

materials.name: Cardboard boxes
instructions: Remove all packing materials (tape OK to leave)
notes: One of the 5 accepted material types in Perth's yellow-lid bin
Large boxes should be flattened and cut down to fit
commonMistakes: Don't include cardboard soaked with grease or food — that goes in FOGO bin
Don't include waxed cardboard

materials.name: Cereal boxes and boxboard
notes: Thin cardboard / boxboard is accepted as cardboard
Part of the 5 accepted material types
commonMistakes: Remove plastic bags and liners inside before recycling
Don't include waxed or foil-lined boxboard

materials.name: Cardboard tubes and rolls
notes: Plain cardboard tubes count as cardboard
commonMistakes: Don't include tubes with foil or plastic lining

materials.name: Aluminium drink cans
notes: One of the 5 accepted material types
Eligible for 10c refund via Containers for Change — consider returning instead
commonMistakes: Don't crush cans — keep 3-dimensional for sorting
Don't include cans with liquid still in them

materials.name: Steel food cans
notes: One of the 5 accepted material types
Steel / tin cans for food are accepted
commonMistakes: Don't include cans with food still in them — rinse first
Don't include aerosol cans — they are NOT accepted in Perth's yellow-lid bin

materials.name: Glass bottles
notes: One of the 5 accepted material types
All colours of glass accepted
Many glass bottles eligible for 10c Containers for Change refund
commonMistakes: Don't include broken glass — wrap in newspaper and place in general waste
Remove metal or plastic lids

materials.name: Glass jars
notes: One of the 5 accepted material types
Labels can stay on
commonMistakes: Don't include ceramic or Pyrex containers — those go in general waste
Remove lids (metal lids go in general waste)

materials.name: Newspaper
instructions: No need to bundle or tie
notes: One of the 5 accepted material types (paper)
Do not bag in plastic
commonMistakes: Don't bag newspapers in plastic
Don't include heavily soiled or wet newspaper — that goes in FOGO

materials.name: Office paper and mail
notes: Paper is one of the 5 accepted material types
Window envelopes accepted — no need to remove plastic window
commonMistakes: Don't include paper towels, tissues, or napkins
Don't include shredded paper — it's too small for sorting

materials.name: Magazines and catalogues
notes: Glossy paper is accepted as paper
Staples OK to leave in
commonMistakes: Don't bag in plastic

materials.name: Junk mail and flyers
notes: Accepted as paper
commonMistakes: Don't include if laminated or plastic-coated

materials.name: Envelopes
notes: Small plastic windows are OK
commonMistakes: Don't include padded envelopes with bubble wrap lining — those go in general waste

materials.name: Phone books and directories
notes: Accepted as paper
commonMistakes: Don't bag in plastic

materials.name: Plastic drink bottles
instructions: REMOVE the lid — lids go in general waste
Place bottle loose in yellow-lid bin
notes: One of the 5 accepted material types
LIDS MUST BE REMOVED — plastic lids are too small for sorting
Many plastic bottles eligible for 10c Containers for Change refund
commonMistakes: ALWAYS remove the lid — lids contaminate recycling and jam machinery
Don't include bottles with liquid still in them
Lids go in your general waste (red-lid) bin

materials.name: Plastic milk bottles
instructions: Remove lid — lids go in general waste
notes: Accepted as plastic bottles/containers
Lids must be removed
commonMistakes: Don't forget to remove the lid
Rinse out milk residue

materials.name: Plastic food containers
instructions: Remove lids — lids go in general waste
notes: One of the 5 accepted material types
Only rigid plastic containers accepted — no soft plastics
commonMistakes: REMOVE LIDS — they jam sorting machinery
Don't include soft plastics, cling wrap, or bags
Don't include foam/polystyrene trays

materials.name: Cleaning product bottles
instructions: Remove trigger sprayer / lid — lids go in general waste
notes: Accepted as plastic containers
Remove trigger sprayers as they jam machinery
commonMistakes: Remove trigger spray tops
Don't include if heavily contaminated with chemicals

materials.name: Shampoo and personal care bottles
instructions: Remove lid/pump — goes in general waste
notes: Accepted as plastic bottles/containers
commonMistakes: Remove pump tops — they aren't recyclable
Squeeze out remaining product

materials.name: Soft plastics and plastic bags
instructions: Some supermarkets have REDcycle drop-off bins
notes: Soft plastics are NOT accepted in Perth's yellow-lid bin
If you can scrunch it into a ball, it's soft plastic
REDcycle program at Coles and Woolworths (check availability)
commonMistakes: Never put soft plastics in the yellow-lid bin — they tangle sorting machinery
Don't put plastic bags in the yellow-lid bin even if they contain recyclables

materials.name: Plastic bottle lids and caps
instructions: Too small for Perth's recycling sorting equipment
notes: Even though the bottle is recyclable, the lid is NOT in Perth
Lids for Change program accepts lids for charity at some locations
commonMistakes: Don't put lids back on bottles before recycling — always remove
Don't put loose lids in the yellow-lid bin

materials.name: Polystyrene and styrofoam
notes: Not accepted in Perth's yellow-lid recycling bin
Includes both food trays and packaging foam
commonMistakes: Don't put foam trays in the yellow-lid bin
Don't include packing peanuts in recycling

materials.name: Disposable coffee cups
instructions: Plastic lids go in general waste too
notes: NOT recyclable in Perth — the plastic lining prevents recycling
Use a reusable cup — many Perth cafés offer discounts
commonMistakes: Don't put coffee cups in the yellow-lid bin — they are NOT recyclable
Don't put the plastic lid in the yellow-lid bin either

materials.name: Coffee cup lids
notes: Too small and wrong plastic type for Perth recycling
commonMistakes: Don't put in the yellow-lid bin

materials.name: Food wrappers and chip packets
notes: Metallised plastic film cannot be recycled
If in doubt, leave it out
commonMistakes: Don't put in the yellow-lid bin

materials.name: Cling wrap and glad wrap
notes: Soft plastic — not accepted in yellow-lid bin
commonMistakes: Don't put in the yellow-lid bin

materials.name: Bubble wrap
notes: Soft plastic — not accepted in yellow-lid bin
commonMistakes: Don't put in the yellow-lid bin

materials.name: Broken glass and crockery
notes: Broken glass contaminates recycling
Ceramics and Pyrex have different melting points to container glass
commonMistakes: Don't put broken glass in the yellow-lid bin — even if it was a bottle
Wrap sharp edges to protect waste collectors

materials.name: Ceramics and crockery
notes: Ceramics cannot be recycled with glass
Different melting point contaminates glass recycling
commonMistakes: Don't put in the yellow-lid bin

materials.name: Drinking glasses and glassware
notes: Drinking glasses have different composition to bottle glass — they contaminate recycling
commonMistakes: Don't put drinking glasses in the yellow-lid bin — they are NOT the same as glass bottles

materials.name: Window glass and mirrors
notes: Treated glass — different composition to container glass
commonMistakes: Don't put in the yellow-lid bin

materials.name: Nappies
instructions: Bag and place in general waste (red-lid) bin
notes: Not recyclable or compostable
commonMistakes: Don't put in the FOGO bin
Don't put in the yellow-lid bin

materials.name: Tissues and paper towels
instructions: Or FOGO bin if only food-soiled (check your council)
notes: Too contaminated for paper recycling
Some Perth councils accept food-soiled paper towels in FOGO
commonMistakes: Don't put in the yellow-lid bin

materials.name: Shredded paper
notes: Too small for sorting machinery — falls through screens
Perth specifically excludes shredded paper from yellow-lid bin
commonMistakes: Don't put shredded paper in the yellow-lid bin — it contaminates other recyclables

materials.name: Greasy pizza boxes
instructions: Tear off clean portions and recycle those in yellow-lid bin
FOGO bin if your council accepts food-soiled cardboard
notes: Grease contaminates paper recycling
Some Perth councils accept food-soiled cardboard in FOGO
commonMistakes: Don't put the whole greasy box in the yellow-lid bin

materials.name: Plastic straws and cutlery
notes: Too small for sorting machinery
WA has banned single-use plastics — switch to reusable
commonMistakes: Don't put in the yellow-lid bin

materials.name: Light bulbs (incandescent and LED)
notes: CFL and fluorescent tubes are hazardous — take to a drop-off point
commonMistakes: Don't put in the yellow-lid bin
Don't confuse with CFL bulbs which need special disposal

materials.name: Pet waste
instructions: Bag and place in general waste (red-lid) bin
notes: Not accepted in FOGO bin
commonMistakes: Don't put in the FOGO bin — even compostable bags

materials.name: Aluminium foil
notes: Perth's yellow-lid bin does NOT accept aluminium foil — only cans
This surprises many people — foil is accepted in some other Australian cities but not Perth
commonMistakes: Don't put aluminium foil in the yellow-lid bin in Perth
Don't confuse with aluminium cans which ARE accepted

materials.name: Aerosol cans
notes: Perth's yellow-lid bin does NOT accept aerosol cans
This differs from some other Australian cities
commonMistakes: Don't put aerosol cans in the yellow-lid bin in Perth
Don't puncture aerosol cans

materials.name: Thermal receipts
notes: Thermal paper contains BPA — contaminates paper recycling
commonMistakes: Don't put receipts in the yellow-lid bin

materials.name: Wax-coated and lined cartons
notes: Perth's yellow-lid bin does NOT accept lined/wax-coated cartons
This is stricter than many other Australian cities
Only the 5 specified material types are accepted
commonMistakes: Don't put milk or juice cartons in the yellow-lid bin in Perth
Don't confuse with cardboard boxes which ARE accepted

materials.name: Food scraps (general)
instructions: Wrap in newspaper or use a council-approved compostable liner
notes: Perth FOGO bins accept all food waste including meat, dairy, and cooked food
Check your specific council for FOGO availability
commonMistakes: Don't use regular plastic bags — only approved compostable liners
Don't put food in general waste if you have FOGO service

materials.name: Fruit and vegetable scraps
notes: All fruit and vegetable scraps accepted
Remove any stickers or rubber bands
commonMistakes: Remove fruit stickers

materials.name: Meat and bones
instructions: Wrap in newspaper to reduce odour
notes: Perth FOGO bins accept all meat and bones including cooked
Industrial composting handles meat and bones safely
commonMistakes: Don't put in general waste if you have FOGO
Wrap in newspaper, not plastic

materials.name: Bread, pasta, and rice
notes: All grain products accepted in FOGO
commonMistakes: Remove plastic packaging first

materials.name: Coffee grounds and tea bags
notes: Coffee grounds and paper tea bags break down well
commonMistakes: Don't include plastic-mesh tea bags — check yours are paper

materials.name: Eggshells
notes: Eggshells add calcium to compost
commonMistakes: Wash is not required
examples: Egg carton (if cardboard) goes in yellow-lid

materials.name: Dairy products
notes: Recycle the container separately in the yellow-lid bin (lid removed)
commonMistakes: Don't put the container in FOGO — only the food waste

materials.name: Garden waste
instructions: Large branches: cut to fit in bin, or take to waste transfer station
notes: FOGO accepts garden organics
Some councils offer additional verge-side green waste collections
commonMistakes: Don't include soil or rocks
Don't include treated timber

materials.name: Grass clippings and leaves
notes: Green and dry leaves both accepted
Leave grass on the lawn if possible (grasscycling)
commonMistakes: Don't bag in plastic — place loose in the bin

materials.name: Food-soiled paper
notes: Paper contaminated with food goes in FOGO, not yellow-lid or general waste
Check your council for specific FOGO acceptance
commonMistakes: Don't put food-soiled paper in the yellow-lid bin — it contaminates recycling

materials.name: Compostable bin liners
instructions: Use Australian Standard AS 4736 certified compostable bags only
Place filled liner in FOGO (green-lid) bin
notes: Only bags carrying the Australian seedling logo are accepted
Regular plastic bags labelled 'biodegradable' are NOT accepted
commonMistakes: Don't use regular plastic bags — even ones marked 'degradable' or 'biodegradable'
Must be AS 4736 certified with the seedling logo

materials.name: Batteries
instructions: Take to a battery drop-off point (Officeworks, Battery World, Aldi stores)
Tape terminals of lithium and 9V batteries before transport
notes: Batteries cause fires in trucks — NEVER put in any kerbside bin
Button batteries are extremely dangerous if swallowed by children
commonMistakes: Never put batteries in any kerbside bin
Tape terminals to prevent short circuits

materials.name: Paint
instructions: Take to a Household Hazardous Waste drop-off event or permanent facility
notes: Paintback program accepts paint at participating retailers
commonMistakes: Don't pour paint down the drain
Don't put liquid paint in any kerbside bin

materials.name: Motor oil and automotive fluids
instructions: Take to a participating workshop or waste facility
Many mechanics accept used oil for free
notes: WA has used oil recycling programs
commonMistakes: Don't pour down drains or on ground
Don't put in any kerbside bin

materials.name: Household chemicals
instructions: Take to a Household Hazardous Waste drop-off event
Check wastesorted.wa.gov.au for events and locations
notes: Never mix chemicals
commonMistakes: Don't pour down drains
Don't put in any kerbside bin

materials.name: Gas bottles and cylinders
instructions: Take to a gas supplier or waste facility
Never put in any kerbside bin
notes: Pressurised containers are explosion risks in waste trucks
commonMistakes: Never puncture
Never put in any kerbside bin

materials.name: Fluorescent tubes and CFL bulbs
instructions: Take to a participating retailer (Bunnings) or waste facility
notes: FluoroCycle program — free drop-off at Bunnings
commonMistakes: Don't put in any kerbside bin
Don't break them — mercury is hazardous

materials.name: Medications
instructions: Return to any pharmacy — RUM (Return Unwanted Medicines) program
Pharmacies accept expired or unwanted medications for free
notes: RUM Project is a free national program
commonMistakes: Don't flush medications
Don't put in any kerbside bin

materials.name: Electronics and e-waste
instructions: Take to an e-waste drop-off point or waste transfer station
notes: E-waste contains valuable recoverable materials
WA has e-waste recycling programs at various locations
commonMistakes: Don't put in any kerbside bin
Wipe personal data first

materials.name: Clothing and textiles
instructions: Donate to charity shops (Vinnies, Salvos, Good Sammy)
Damaged textiles: check council for textile recycling
notes: Perth has many charity bins and op shops
Good Sammy is a WA-specific charity
commonMistakes: Don't put in any kerbside bin
Don't donate wet or heavily soiled items

materials.name: Large appliances
instructions: Check your council for verge-side bulk waste collection
Or take to a waste transfer station
Some scrap metal dealers accept for free
notes: Many Perth councils offer annual bulk waste collection
commonMistakes: Don't dump illegally
Don't put in any kerbside bin
Remove doors from fridges for safety

materials.name: Mattresses
instructions: Check your council for verge-side bulk waste collection
Or take to a waste transfer station
Some mattress recyclers operate in Perth
notes: Mattresses take up significant landfill space — recycling preferred
commonMistakes: Don't dump on the verge outside collection times

materials.name: Tyres
instructions: Take to a tyre retailer or waste facility
Most tyre shops accept old tyres when you buy new ones
notes: Tyres are banned from landfill in WA
Tyre Stewardship Australia program
commonMistakes: Don't dump illegally
Don't put in any kerbside bin

materials.name: Containers for Change (10c refund)
instructions: Take eligible containers to a Containers for Change refund point
Eligible containers have a 10c refund mark
Find your nearest refund point at containersforchange.com.au
notes: Most aluminium cans, glass bottles, plastic bottles, and cartons between 150ml–3L are eligible
Refund is 10 cents per container
Wine bottles, plain milk bottles, and cordial over 1L are NOT eligible
commonMistakes: Not all containers are eligible — look for the 10c mark
Don't crush containers — they need the barcode for scanning

recycle: Cardboard — flattened boxes, cereal boxes, boxboard, cardboard tubes
Aluminium and steel cans — clean and empty, not crushed
Glass bottles and jars — clean and empty, lids removed
Paper — newspaper, office paper, magazines, envelopes, junk mail (NOT shredded)
Plastic bottles and containers — clean and empty, LIDS REMOVED
compost: All food scraps — fruit, vegetables, meat, bones, dairy, bread, grains
Coffee grounds, paper tea bags, paper filters
Garden waste — prunings, weeds, grass clippings, leaves
Certified compostable bin liners (AS 4736 seedling logo only)
trash: Soft plastics, plastic bags, cling wrap, bubble wrap
Wax-coated / lined cartons (milk cartons, Tetra Pak)

recycle: Plastic bottle lids and caps (too small for sorting)
Lined cartons (milk cartons, Tetra Pak, juice boxes)
Ceramics, crockery, drinking glasses, window glass
compost: Regular plastic bags (even if labelled biodegradable)

tips: Perth's yellow-lid bin accepts ONLY 5 material types — if in doubt, leave it out!
ALWAYS remove lids from plastic bottles and containers before recycling — lids go in general waste
All items must be clean, empty, and placed LOOSE in the bin — never bag recyclables
Aluminium foil, aerosol cans, and lined cartons are NOT accepted in Perth — unlike some other cities
Use Containers for Change refund points for 10c per eligible container (containersforchange.com.au)
FOGO (green-lid) bin accepts all food scraps plus garden waste — check your council for availability
Rules vary slightly between Perth councils (WMRC, City of Perth, City of Bayswater, City of Stirling)
Check wastesorted.wa.gov.au for item-specific disposal guidance
WA has banned single-use plastics — bring your own bags and reusable cups
Household Hazardous Waste events run regularly — check your council website

locations.name: Containers for Change Refund Points
locations.notes: 10c refund per eligible container. Multiple locations across Perth metro area.

locations.name: WMRC Recycling Centre
locations.notes: Free for WMRC member council residents (Claremont, Cottesloe, Mosman Park, Peppermint Grove, Subiaco).

locations.name: Bunnings (various locations)
locations.notes: Free drop-off for CFL/fluorescent tubes and paint. Multiple Perth locations.

locations.name: Charity Clothing Bins (Good Sammy, Salvos, Vinnies)
locations.notes: Located throughout Perth metro area. Good Sammy is a WA-specific charity.
